lines.text: I cannot admire a man with no morals.
Clarry, men put on their morals as we put on our stays!
If you marry Soames I swear you will become the youngest and prettiest widow in the county.
I could have loved him.
I will see her.
Then you'll have to kill me first.
Do not be sad. I am not sad. Rejoice with me that all my worldly troubles are so near an end.
Her grandmother came to me, begged me to be merciful.
And you agreed?
Word of a gentleman, Jack.
[refusing Lovelace's marriage proposal]
I would not bind myself in covenant with you for a thousand, thousand worlds.

[after he has raped Clarissa]
I love you.
Some new strategem?
Believe me.
Again? Like I believed Captain Tomlinson and Lady Betty? How you all must have laughed. Such a witty masquerade.

[talking about Lovelace]
Heir to a peerage, a fine paternal estate, two unmarried aunts. Mark that.
And an army of whores and bastards. Mark that.
I have always heard that you prefer not to confine your pleasure to more than one lady entirely.
[after Clarissa has fled from home, her family are trying to find her. Her brother goes to see her best friend]
Even if I knew where she was, which I don't, my mother has forbidden me to write.
Surely you do not mean to frustrate any hopes we have of a reconciliation?
On whose terms?

[to Anna's mother]
Is it a daughter's place to bandy terms?
Or a brother's to impose them? If my friend wishes to be reconciled, I'm sure she remembers your address.
Where is she?
It's not my fault.
Bob. Stop now. Before you do something you regret.
Now mother, what workman throws away a sharp tool because it may prick his finger.
You know the rules. No letters.
Not even to Anna?
Your go-between to Lovelace?

[writing to Anna]
You once told me adversity was my shining time, and so I think it is.
Dig a hole deep enough to conceal this unhappy body for I fear that those who would not stir to protect me living will move heaven and earth to defend me dead.
I should as soon die here as anywhere.
Spare us a shilling squire, spare us a shilling for an old soldier.
You tell me that my uncle, a man I never knew to lie, now requires me to pretend I am already married?
Look at me sir, not at him.
Has she gone? Thank God for that, I can get out of this fancy dress.
My soul is above you, man. Do not urge me to tell you how much I know my soul is above you.
My soul is above you. But my body...
What on earth took him so long?
I've never heard such a-doings in all my life. Such a chicken of a gentleman and a tiger of a lady.
She can use her airs and graces to satisfy some of our young gentlemen.
She's not getting any comfort from me. She's one of us now.
Kindness, Bella, would suit you better.

[reading from one of Clarissa's stolen letters]
Look carefully to the seals of my letters.
Muslin? I wanted silk, Miss Lyons, with ruffles here and here.
No other man will have you now.
[showing a letter from Clarissa]
Mine, Jack, Mine!
[Reading the letter]
Hmm. It's more like a sermon than a billet-doux.
Clarry, a woman must know when to bend or else she will surely break.
Pinch your cheeks, Bella. Your face must be your fortune now.
How cruel of you to rob Bella of the only lover she ever had.
Me? It wasn't me. She refused him.
[discussing the possible return of Clarissa]
No! If she ever enters these doors, I shall leave.
Then leave. The child has suffered enough.
Was Lovelace here?
He's gone now.
Can he never leave me in peace? Will he pursue me to the grave?
[Talking about Lovelace]
Don't you like him at all? Not even a teeny bit? He's so handsome.
So wild!
So vain!
I know these promising ladies, you see, all sauce and no stuffing. 50 guineas on it she flies the nest.
Impersonate me with your strumpets!
[after Lovelace has raped Clarissa]
What further evils are reserved for me? I find I am your prisoner.
I trust you slept well.
I did not sleep.
Scribbling? Is that wise? Letters can be traced.
As you should know.
I hope at least you used an alias.
I leave all such subterfuge to you.
[Grandfather Harlowe has died and left the entire estate and wealth to his younger granddaughter, Clarissa]
Imagine! Leaving all the family paintings to her, just because she used to tickle with him! And wipe and clean with her own dainty fingers.

[taking Bella's hand]
Dainty? Whose fingers could be daintier than these?
He might just as well have left them to the maid.
[as Clarissa is dying in prison, her coffin is brought into her cell]
What shocking sight is this?
Why shocking? Are we shocked in church to see the monuments of our ancestors with whom we hope one day to rest in peace?
Mr Hickman is very patient, but no man will wait forever.
Don't Mr Lovelace say you have fine eyes?
Is that what he told you?
Oh she may threaten, she may weep, she may rave 'Oh you traitor! Oh you fiend!' but little by little she comes to like her little cage.
Well done Jack, you have avenged her well. One man cannot have every woman worth having... Clarissa let this redeem my soul.
Men are all such nasty schoolboys.
What a choice. Soames, the grubby little sneakthief or Lovelace, the schoolyard bully.
Ain't I the regular blaggard!

[contemplating a union between Clarissa and Lovelace]
But from the point of view of the estate, as long as Bella don't object.
Why should I object? She's welcome to my leavings.
I swear

[interrupting]
No oaths, sir. Oaths won't do it. Not your oaths leastways.

[on arriving at the Sinclair house in Dover Street, Clarissa is welcomed as Mrs Lovelace]
*Mrs* Lovelace?
The lady is a very moral woman. What more could I do?
I would rather you did less, Mr Lovelace, not more.
Have a care, Mr Harlowe.
James, why must you be so spiteful?
Do you think to make me your whore?
Your swains follow you everywhere!
